stimulusHtml: Two point charges, one with positive charge +2Q and one with negative charge -Q, are fixed in place a distance D apart. The electric potential energy of the two-point charge system is U0. If a third, positive, point charge is added to the system, where should the third point charge be located so that the electric potential energy of the three-point charge system is still U0? What evidence or reasoning supports the claim?
choicesHtml: Closer to the +2Q point charge. The third point charge should be closer to the original point charge with the larger-magnitude charge.
Closer to the +2Q point charge. The third point charge should be closer to the original point charge of the same sign.
Closer to the -Q point charge. The third point charge should be closer to the original point charge with the smaller-magnitude charge.
Closer to the -Q point charge. The third point charge should be closer to the original point charge of the opposite sign.
